But just sticking it out isn't a measure of success.
In fact, people around the country are weighing this idea that neighborhood violence can cause trauma that should be treated.
In California, a handful of families sued the Compton School District, arguing that trauma is a disability that schools should accommodate.
Baltimore is putting workers citywide through training to detect and understand trauma in the communities they serve.
And so there are still a lot of questions for the Urban Warriors program in Chicago.
How do you know if a kid is coping better?
What about the vets?
Does mentoring help them deal with PTSD?
The program's founders have brought in University of Chicago researchers to study the people who have been through the programs so far to try to answer those questions.

And for Jim Courtney-Clarks and the vets of Urban Warriors, it's a start.
My co-host, Robert Siegel, first visited Paris 49 years ago.
Paris is a city he loves.
And after terrorists struck last Friday, his first instinct was to get there.
This week, he's brought us his conversations with Parisians from all walks of life.
Today, he has these thoughts about what he's seen.
There is no simple slogan this time - no je suis Charlie or je suis Ahmed.
There's been no rallying of French men and women by the millions to declare their solidarity and no arm-in-arm march of world leaders to this spot, the Place de la Republique.

Perhaps there will yet be some event echoing those displays of fraternite that we saw in January, when another set of killers chose their targets from among minorities here - cartoonists at a provocative weekly, Jews at a kosher grocery.
A declaration of solidarity made sense then.
It was the defiant response to an attack at the fissures of French society, the cracks between those who stand out and the masses who blend in.
This time, such a declaration hardly seems necessary.
The Parisians who were targeted last Friday did not court controversy by publishing anyone's blasphemies.
All they did was go to a rock concert or a soccer match, a Cambodian restaurant or a neighborhood bistro.
What was under attack was nothing extraordinary or offensive.
The targeted sites implied no special affiliation.
The victims were as diverse as Paris itself.

One woman I met paying tribute to victims last Sunday told me it was an attack on the idea of democracy, the idea that you can out at night, that women be at cafes, that men can go where they please and the fact that you should respect what your neighbor thinks.
I've thought about her words a lot all week.
It strikes me that we don't always describe democracy in such banal terms.
No one ever summed up the French Enlightenment by saying, I disapprove of what you order at the cafe, but I will defend to the death your right to order it.
But what happened here shows there is a real connection between big ideas about freedom and small, casual acts of friendship and recreation.
One person publishing a biting satire and another reacting to it over a bite at the bistro are two sides of the same coin.
The gunmen and suicide bombers who came here claiming divine authority understood that.
The guns that were aimed at the few in January were fired without distinction in November.
Everyone was a target.
The French are Charlie.
And in their grief, they need no reminding of it.
This is Robert Siegel in Paris.
New Bedford, now a run down old fishing port on the coast of Massachusetts - not far from Cape Code - was once known as The City that Lit the World.
Back in the 1800s, New Bedford produced much of the whale oil that fueled lamps across the country.
Those glory days are long gone.
The city is now beset by high crime, unemployment and other issues of urban decay.
But officials are trying to be playing the city's fame as an energy hub, this time using a more sustainable kind of power - offshore wind.
From member station WBUR in Boston, Asma Khalid has our story.
(SOUNDBITE OF WATER RIPPLING)
For generations, water was New Bedford's lifeblood, the source of its wealth.
The water is still here, but the wealth is gone.
These days, you notice just a glimmer of New Bedford's old opulence in the stained glass windows of the old whaling captain's mansions.
But, Mayor Jon Mitchell remembers it well.
On the eve of the Civil War, that New Bedford was the wealthiest city per capita in the Untied States.
New Bedford was to whaling what Detroit was to automobiles.
Mayor Mitchell is trying to recreate those riches, and, fortunately, he says his city is sitting on the Saudi Arabia of wind.
The federal government has grand plans for offshore wind farms - from Maine all the way to South Carolina.
But, no American port is currently capable of towing huge wind turbines out into the ocean.
That's where Massachusetts wants to step in.
Last month, the state began construction on a port in New Bedford that will be big enough to transport wind blades the length of a football field.
The hope is that it will help New Bedford become the hub for offshore wind.
And with it, bring something this city desperately needs - jobs.
Even though fishing remains valuable, the current unemployment rate is one of the worst in the state.
(SOUNDBITE OF STREET NOISE)
Justin Sylvia wakes up at 3:30 in the morning to drive more than an hour to get to his job as a heavy equipment operator.
He says he would love to find work closer to home, so he could spend time with his three kids.
He's trying to land himself a job on this port project, and says lots of his friends are too.
There's definitely a big buzz in the area as far as how many jobs it's going to create.
I mean, I know that's the main focus is get as many New Bedford unemployed workers that are capable and trained properly.
The Department of Energy estimates that by 2030 - if the U.S.
takes advantage of its wind potential - some 200,000 jobs could sprout up around the offshore wind industry.
Mayor Mitchell wants his city to grab a bulk of them.
